subject: Economics
title: The Kuznets Curve: Does Growth Fix Inequality?
description: A fast breakdown of The Kuznets Curve: Does Growth Fix Inequality? for builders.

hook.text: Simon Kuznets proposed a comforting idea: inequality rises during industrialization, then falls as nations get richer.

buildup.text: The evidence seemed perfect. Industrial Britain and America saw inequality rise.

discovery.text: Kuznets won a Nobel Prize. Policymakers relaxed: just focus on growth, and equality will follow naturally.

twist.text: Since 1980, inequality has surged in every developed nation. The curve didn't turn down again.

climax.text: The mid-century equality wasn't automatic â€” it was built by policy: progressive taxes, strong unions, public education.

punchline.text: Growth doesn't cure inequality. Policy does.

quiz.question: Why did the Kuznets curve theory prove incomplete?
options: Post-1980 rising inequality showed that declining inequality was driven by policy choices, not automatic growth
